fields.name: Date gathered

views.name: Add patient vital signs
views.title: Patient vital signs intake form
views.description: This form facilitates adding up-to-date patient information at the time of the emergency admission.

field_options.description: Enter a unique identifier for this set of patient details. E.g., 2021-12-30 10:00 75
Select the patient to whom this set of data pertains.
A patient's condition should be described in detail, citing symptoms and other relevant details.
Assess or inquire about the patient's level of pain on a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 representing the most excruciating.
Log the patient's body temperature. E.g., 98.7
Enter the patient's blood pressure reading. E.g., 120/80
Enter the patient's pulse rate. E.g., 65
Enter the patient's respiratory rate. E.g., 17
Enter the patient's blood oxygen level. E.g., 90 mm Hg
Does the patient have a smoking habit?
How often does the patient consume alcoholic beverages?
If the patient is currently taking any medications, list them here.
Log the patient's current height in centimeters.
Log the patient's current weight in kilograms.

rows.field_362132: Bruised lower leg from falling of a tree.
Deep cut on finger from chopping vegetables for dinner.
Car accident victim and was crying in pain.

A man who is 24 and in good health asks the triage nurse. He says he can't see his dentist until next week and asked for medication for the pain. He says the pain started yesterday and is a 10/10 on the pain scale. There is no obvious facial swelling.
rows.field_363475: There shouldn't be any need for resources. He will have to get a physical, but if there are no signs of an abscess or cellulites, he will be sent to a dentist. In the ED, he might get pills to take by mouth and prescriptions for antibiotics and/or painkillers. Even though he says his pain is 10/10, he is not an ESI level 2. Based on the assessment at triage, he would not get the last available bed.

rows.field_362132: A man who is 45 years old comes to the ED and asks to be checked. He is very allergic to shellfish, but he accidentally ate a dip that had shrimp in it. He felt his throat start to close up right away, so he took his epinephrine. He tells you that he's doing fine. No coughing or rashes were seen.
rows.field_363475: Injected epinephrine a few minutes ago.

rows.field_357940: Patient conditions that endanger the patient's life, limb, or organ.
rows.field_357942:
Patient requires immediate life-saving intervention? 

Immediate life-saving intervention required: airway, emergency medications, or other hemodynamic interventions (IV, supplemental O2, monitor, ECG, or labs DO NOT count); and/or any of the following clinical conditions: intubated, apneic, pulseless, severe respiratory distress, SPO2<90, acute mental status changes, or unresponsive. 
Unresponsiveness is defined as a patient that is either:
(1) nonverbal and not following commands (acutely); or
(2) requires a noxious stimulus (P or U on AVPU) scale

rows.field_357940: Patient conditions that pose a threat to life, limb, organ, or function.
rows.field_357942:
The patient is in a high-risk situation, confused/lethargic/disoriented, or in severe pain/distress? 
 
A high-risk situation is a patient you would put in your last open bed. 
Severe pain/distress is determined by clinical observation and/or patient rating of greater than or equal to 7 on the 0-10 pain scale.

rows.field_357940: Serious conditions that necessitate immediate treatment.
rows.field_357942:
The patient requires many resources and vital signs tests.
 
Danger Zone Vital Signs
Consider uptriage to ESI 2 if any vital sign criterion is exceeded.
 
Pediatric Fever Considerations
• 1 to 28 days of age: assign at least ESI 2 if temp >38.0 C (100.4F)
• 1-3 months of age: consider assigning ESI 2 if temp >38.0 C (100.4F)
• 3 months to 3 yrs of age: consider assigning ESI 3 if: temp >39.0 C (102.2 F), or incomplete immunizations, or no obvious source of fever 
 
Resources: Count the number of different types of resources, not the individual tests or x-rays (examples: CBC, electrolytes and coags equal one resource; CBC plus chest x-ray equals two resources). 
 
Resources
• Labs (blood, urine)
• ECG, X-rays
• CT-MRI-ultrasound-angiography
• IV fluids (hydration)
• IV or IM or nebulized medications
• Specialty consultation
• Simple procedure =1 (lac repair, foley cath)
• Complex procedure =2 (conscious sedation)

rows.field_357940: Conditions that are associated with patient distress or probable complications that require attention.
rows.field_357942:
This patient requires just one resource. 
 
Resources
• Labs (blood, urine)
• ECG, X-rays
• CT-MRI-ultrasound-angiography
• IV fluids (hydration)
• IV or IM or nebulized medications
• Specialty consultation
• Simple procedure =1 (lac repair, foley cath)
• Complex procedure =2 (conscious sedation)

rows.field_357940: Non-urgent conditions or those that may be associated with a chronic condition.
rows.field_357942: Doctor consultation - patient needs an exam and prescription.
